main_text:
William Crathorn (fl. 1330s), like Adam Wodeham (d. 1358) and Robert
Holkot (c. 1290–1349), belonged to the first generation of
Oxford philosophers after William of Ockham (c. 1285–1347), who
sought to criticize and develop Ockham’s philosophy. Crathorn is
remembered for his theories of language and cognition, and for some
anti-skeptical arguments strikingly similar to those found in
Descartes’ Meditations. The radical ontology of his
works is also noteworthy, though it has not yet been closely
studied.
